messageBody:
There are two issues here:

(1) Assertion failures are the bit of JUnit that deteremines whether your
test has passed or failed. If you catch AssertionFailedException in your
tests you'll always get a green light!

Nevertheless you are right to want to protect your users from failed
assertions. I would argue that you do this by not including any JUnit code
in your deployment to the live environment. Test cases & suites should be
separate bits of code. I'm working with Oracle JDeveloper (I must have been
very bad in a previous existence) and that has a Jar tool that allows you to
exclude individual classes from a package. I assume most other IDEs other
something similar.

(2) Exceptions thrown by a failure in the code should be trapped. That's
obvious. The question is whether they should be checked exceptions or not.
Checked exceptions have to be caught but you don't have to do anything with
them. This code:
try {
doSomeMethod();
}
catch (Exception e) {}
"handles" any checked exception thrown by doSomeMethod() but doesn't
actually do anything with it.

I wrote a ExceptionHandler to generically handle exceptions (retrieve and
format meaningful error messages from database table, log serious errors,
etc.). The problem is propagation: if you are throwing exceptions upwards
you can't have an error handler using checked exceptions otherwise you end
up coding:
try {
doSomeMethod();
}
catch (Exception e) {
try {
doErrorHandling(e);
}
catch (PropagatedException pe) {
}

}
and you're no better off! That's why I sub-classed PropagatedException from
RuntimeException.

IMHO "Programming By Contact" is a cool idea but a pain to implement;
consequently unless there are adequate quality procedures in place
developers will circumvent checked exceptions whenever that's the easiest
option (if my own behaviour is any yardstick). If you're working in a
component-building shop by all means throw lots of bespoke exceptions. Just
don't be under any illusions that the developers will do anything meaningful
with them The catch(Exception e) {} compiles and at least the user is
presented with an ugly error stack but the code *still doesn't work*

regards, APC

--- In junit@egroups.com, Robert Sartin <sartin@a...> wrote:
>
> --- Robert Sartin <sartin@a...> wrote:
> >Assertion failures should be caught. Meyer is right on this.
>
> Once more with feeling and correctness:
>
> Assertion failures should *never* be caught. Meyer is right on this.

What about in a production system where I don't want a poor end user
to be troubled with 20 or so lines of exception stack trace, and more
importantly, I want to ask them very nicely to report the error to
tech support.

Or even worse, it's a Web app and Joe Public is using it, and I want
to redirect them to an ever-so-nice error page.

Or even even worse, it's a web app and the client is using it from
home one night just before he signs the final cheque...
